data.sampled: 80 seconds. The bottle will lose as much liquid through leakage as John adds every second (1-(-0.2)). This means that each second, net of loss through leaking, he is adding 1/0.8=1.25 oz of liquid to the bottle. Thus, filling the entire 16oz takes him 16/1.25=12.8 sec (rounded down from 13). Given that we can't have fractional time intervals like "seconds," I rounded up an extra half-second to ensure my answer doesn't violate your request for whole numbers only! And since we want WHOLE seconds, I also rounded up another full second since there is a non-zero chance that due to floating point errors, etc., 12.9 might actually be greater than or equal to 14 (which is when you round DOWN to the nearest whole second in integer math), so given that possibility of error too, the ANSWER IS: 13 seconds (within small margin of statistical error).

4 days per week. (18-9)/5=4 days. 
She trained for three hours on 3 days.
So she trained for five hours on 7-3 =4 days.
And these four days were spread throughout the week. There were not enough days to have her train two or more consecutive days at this duration. So she must have trained for five hours exactly once every one of those days which is equivalent to saying each individual occurrence was separated from all others by one intervening period of time. In conclusion: Annie trained for five hours on exactly 4 days out of that given 7 day week and on none of the other days did she train as much as five hours despite the fact that she may have trained longer than normal on certain other days during that same week.. 14.  The first problem I have here is that this appears to be an attempt at an IQ test.  Too many constraints for my taste!   Let N = the number we're looking for.

We know:
N+2 ------> Smallest
N-----Large
(N-2)x2 = 28. This tells us that N-2 = 7 or (N-2)=5.

Since N must be odd, N=5. So, the answer is 7.
The number 5 occurs twice because it sits right smack dab in between two multiples of 2 which makes it doubly special. It also satisfies the conditions set forth in the question.
